Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Automated Real-time Production of Political Indicators

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Systematic indicators of political characteristics such as regime type, internal instability, and inter-state conflict have been widely used in political and economic research over the past three decades and are increasingly used in policy applications. There has been limited effort to automate the production of such indicators, which are generally produced by individual research projects using human coders and are widely available only after a considerable delay. Improvements in computer software and hardware, meanwhile, have made the process of analyzing large bodies of text to extract meaningful information much more efficient. Automated coding is transparent, without the unreproducible subjective elements of human coding, and once the source texts have been prepared, recoding to account for new theoretical or technological perspectives can be done quickly and efficiently. Using extant tools for automated coding, this project will produce near real-time political indicators that will be comparable, if not identical, to indicators produced by human coding. The project first creates data on the interaction events of nations in the current century. In addition, the project will extract measurements of the characteristics and behaviors of governments, including human rights practices and the level of autocracy. Finally, the project will construct information about the interstate disputes among nations.

In the realm of world politics, most scientific analysis is based on data that are at least a decade old. This research will significantly reduce the time-lag between events in the contemporary world and systematic measurement and analysis of those events in the academic and policy arena by reducing to weeks from decades the delay with which systematic data are made publicly available. Moreover, this project will expose these data in a transparent and widely accessible way. Not only will the data be available to those who collected the data, but they will be freely accessible to any and all via a web interface. The project will permit recent patterns and changes, such as the rise of China, to be more readily reflected in scientific research on world affairs. This should provide a continuing foundation for more accurate and increasingly credible understandings of politics at the global level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Political event data, which are abbreviated statistical summaries of interactions that have been reported in newspapers and wire services, have been used since the 1970s for the study of international and domestic conflict by the academic community, government agencies, and non-government organizations. Over the past twenty-five years, largely under sponsorship from the NSF Political Science program, and NSF Methods, Measurement and Statistics program, the methods for generating this data have transitioned from labor intensive human coding to fully automated coding, and the coding frameworks have been updated to reflect post-Cold War concerns, particularly actions by non-state militarized groups. Statistical models based on event data have been shown in numerous studies to be far more accurate in predicting conflicts than the accuracy exhibited by the typical political expert using non-statistical methods.

This project built on the foundation of earlier work to produce a completely open, fully automated system which uses news reports downloaded from the Web. The system is currently being used by the new Open Event Data Alliance (OEDA) to produce the freely-available Phoenix event data set (http://phoenixdata.org/) that is updated daily, and the system is designed so that it could be deployed by any research group and customized. The system generating Phoenix has now been running since July 2014 and is completely stable.

The NSF-funded research included the following:

  • Development of a new coding engine named PETRARCH which is written in the Python programming language, replacing the older TABARI program from 2000 which was written in the C/C++ language. PETRARCH uses the output from the open source Stanford CoreNLP natural language processor to provide more accurate identification of "who did what to whom" than the older, pattern-based system did.
  • In collaboration with Virginia-based Caerus Associates and the NSF-funded Penn State "Big Data Social Science" IGERT program, a "pipeline"—EL:DIABLO—was written that starts by downloading news articles from the web, processes these with CoreNLP and PETRARCH, adds geographical coding, removes duplicates, and then posts the resulting data to a web site. This system can be deployed in a "cloud" server and runs without any supervision, so real-time data can be generated at almost no cost.
  • The dictionaries used by PETRARCH to identify political actors and their activities were substantially updated, particularly by incorporating synonym sets from the open-access WordNet data base. Actor dictionaries were updated to incorporate the names of militarized groups from various data bases on terrorist activities, and information on pre-Cold War political transitions such as the decolonization in the 1950s and 1960s were added so that the dictionaries could be used for coding long baseline data sets such as a New York Times-based set which OEDA is developing in conjunction with the Cline Center at the University of Illinois: this will go back to 1945.

All of the software and dictionaries are openly available at the GitHub site  http://openeventdata.github.com/. Because of intellectual property constraints, the texts used to generate the coded events cannot be shared, but the Phoenix data records include the URLs from which the texts were obtained, which means these can be filtered by source and in many instances could be downloaded.

This project did not develop any new statistical forecasting models, but these are widely available both in the academic literature and are being used in U.S. government projects such as the Integrated Conflict Early Warning System (ICEWS) and the Political Instability Task Force.
